qas.question: When was the administrative county of Lancashire created?
What is the area served by the Lord-Lieutenant called now?
Where is the ancient border between Lancashire and Yorkshire located?
Why is Lancashire smaller than its historical extent?
What area is covered by the Lord-Lieutenant?

answers.text: the administrative county and the county boroughs

qas.question: When was the city of Liverpool established?
What county lies north of Lancashire?
What's the main river in Todmorden?
What county lies north of the River Mersey?
In what year was Cheshire made a county?

context: Lancashire is smaller than its historical extent following a major <a3_0>reform of local government<a3_0/>. In <a0_0><b5_0><b9_0>1889<b9_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>, the administrative county of Lancashire was created, covering the historical county except for the county boroughs such as Blackburn, Burnley, Barrow-in-Furness, Preston, Wigan, Liverpool and Manchester. The area served by the Lord-Lieutenant (termed now a <a1_0>ceremonial county<a1_0/>) covered the entirety of <a4_0>the administrative county and the county boroughs<a4_0/>, and was expanded whenever boroughs annexed areas in neighbouring counties such as Wythenshawe in <b6_0>Manchester<b6_0/> south of the <b7_0>River Mersey<b7_0/> and historically in <b8_0>Cheshire<b8_0/>, and southern Warrington. It did not cover <a2_0>the western part of Todmorden<a2_0/>, where the ancient border between Lancashire and Yorkshire passes through the middle of the town.
